qas.question: What do all commonly used video compression methods use?
What is not used in practical products?
What do all commonly used fractals use?
What is not used in DWT?

plausible_answers.text: N. Ahmed, T. Natarajan and K. R. Rao

context: Today, nearly all commonly used video compression methods (e.g., those in standards approved by the <b6_0>ITU-T or ISO<b6_0/>) apply a <a0_0><b3_0>discrete cosine transform<b3_0/><a0_0/> (DCT) for <a1_0><b4_0>spatial redundancy reduction<b4_0/><a1_0/>. The DCT that is widely used in this regard was introduced by <b7_0>N. Ahmed, T. Natarajan and K. R. Rao<b7_0/> in 1974. Other methods, such as <a2_0><b5_0>fractal compression<b5_0/><a2_0/>, matching pursuit and the use of a discrete wavelet transform (DWT) have been the subject of some research, but are typically not used in practical products (except for the use of wavelet coding as still-image coders without motion compensation). Interest in fractal compression seems to be waning, due to recent theoretical analysis showing a comparative lack of effectiveness of such methods.
